column3: NEW_SCENE

J.D.'s bedroom. "Away" by Leroy begins to play. Close up of a digital clock clicking over from 5:59 to 6:00. The alarm goes off and a sock-covered foot reaches over to tap it off. Pull back to reveal J.D., in pajama bottoms and a t-shirt, stretched sideways across his disheveled bed. He sits up.
Since I was a kid, I've been able to sleep through anything - storms, sirens, you name it. Last night, I didn't sleep.
I guess I get a little goofy when I'm nervous.
You see, today isn't just any other day. It's my first day.
I'm the man.
And four years of pre-med, four years of med school, and tons of unpaid loans have made me realize one thing...
Good. Could you go drop an NG tube on the patient in 234, and call the attending that the lavage is positive?
I don't know jack.
NEW_SCENE
So, this is my story.
Uh, I'm supposed to be up in intensive care.
Good. We just turfed him there.
Look, I became a doctor because I wanted to help people. But orientation yesterday... it didn't really focus on patient care.
The hospital doesn't want to be sued. Being sued is not a good thing.
Hey, Turk.
'Sup.
You know how I'm totally down with the rap music?
Dude, be whiter.
Chris Turk's my best friend. We roomed together in college...
We roomed together in med school...
Hell, we even got accepted by the same hospital.
Here's the thing: TuPac, DMX, Dr. Dre, in most of their songs, these artists use an extremely volatile racial slur... the "N" word.
I got it.
Right. My question is this: if we're both singing along, and knowing that otherwise I would never use the word, am I allowed to say-
No.
See, that's good for me to know. I didn't-I didn't know that.
Finally, doctors, if there is a mistake, don't admit it to the patient. Of course, if the patient is deceased, and you're sure, you can feel free to tell him or her... anything.
Hey, listen, I found us an apartment....
Okay, gang. I'm Dr. Bob Kelso, and I'm your Chief of Medicine. So, I just want to encourage you all to think of me as your safety net. Because, I promise you, we're family here.
Now, then, go get 'em, doctors.
NEW_SCENE
So, the surgical interns are gonna go grab a beer.
The medical interns are having a PacMan tournament.
...Apparently we're all twelve.
I love PacMan.
Me too. I love watching it, I love playing it, I love all of it.
I'm Elliot.
Eeellliiiiooott...
Yeah. Don't do that.
I'm J.D., this is Turk.
Elliot, are you medical, or surgical?
Medical.
Heh-heh. Hello.
So, every male in my family is a doctor: my dad, my grand-dad, and my brother. I guess that's why dad gave me a guy's name, made me play sports, date girls. I'm joking.
I know. I would have laughed if you'd paused.
Anyway, I know what you're thinking.
Your butt looks like two Pringles hugging.
No you don't.
I'm probably "Miss Hyper Competitive". I mean, it used to be a big problem for me. "Used to" - past tense.
Hey, are we, like, racing?
Yes!
Please. I'm not that desperate.
So, you do a lot of cardio, or...?
Oh, yeah.
Elliot Reid? John Dorian? Great. One: I am your resident, Dr. Jeffrey Steadman - not "Jeff". Two: Here are your manuals. This -
You ever notice how quickly some people make an impression?
I'm a tool. I'm a tool. I'm a tool, tool, tool, an unbelievably annoying tool.
Yeah.
Yeah. Finally, these are your beepers . From now on, they control your entire life. 'Kay? Thanks. Move it.
Back to today.
NEW_SCENE
Uh, I was paged.
Aww, first day, Bambi? Carla will take care of you. Don't look at me when we're moving someone.
Why?
We're waiting for Dr. Cox.
Hi, doctor, I'm-
Place an IV for me.
We'll talk later.
Carla, can I ask you a personal question? Do you spray the perfume on or just fill your bathtub up and splash around in it?
I smell nice.
Come on, you've done this to cadavers before. So this guy's alive, just poke it through his skin! Poke it through! Now!
Time's up. Carla, would you do it for him, please? I also need an A.B.G.
Why are you telling her?
Shut up and watch.
Be nice to Bambi!
Why does this GOMER got to try and die everyday during my lunch?
That's a little insensitive.
Mistake.
Man's 92 years old, he has full dementia, he doesn't even know we're here, he's inches from Carla's rack and he hasn't even flinched.
Aww, that is so sweet.
Yeah, it is.
What about his subconscious?
Eisenhower was a sissy.
I think by the grace of God we're gonna be okay. Oh, and from now on, whenever I'm in the room, you're definitely not allowed to talk.
NEW_SCENE
Now...Dr. Dorian, can you tell me what ailment most often....
I think I'm gonna love rounds. It's like being on a gameshow.
What is euremia?
That's my boy!
Hey, nice, clean job on the foley catheter.
I'd had a nurse do it. Unfortunately, I'm still afraid to touch anybody.
I've been thinking a lot about Elliot.
...A whole lot.
Dr. Reid, you're late.
I got puked on.
You're off the hook if you can tell me what to look for in a euremic patient.
Anyway...I'm going for it.
Infection.
Infection?
That's my girl!
Moving on.
I knew the answer!
I'm sure you did.
I was just frazzled.
Well, how could you not be....
You know with the...
Oh, I know. Yeah.
Good. But thanks. If there's anything I can ever do for you, just
You could let me take you to dinner tomorrow night.
Around seven.... Or eight.
Why not.
NEW_SCENE
Why not. That's what she said. "Why not"!
Daddy, why did you marry mommy?
Well, Tiger, I gave her an answer during rounds, and she screwed my brains out.
You the man!
What the hell are you doing?
Did you actually just page me to find out how much Tylenol to give to Mrs. Lendsner?
I was worried that it could exacerbate the patient's
It's regular-strength Tylenol! Here's what'cha do: Get her to open her mouth, take a handful, and throw it at her. Whatever sticks, that's the correct dosage.
But I
And under no circumstances are you to compromise our "no talking" agreement.
Dr. Kelso, he's always telling me, you know, "You've gotta stay positive!"
I'm gonna go ahead and say this just as carefully as possible so I don't overstate it: Dr. Kelso is the most evil human being on the planet. And may, in fact, be Satan, himself.
It's just that, this isn't really what I expected... You know...
Most of my patients are, uh...older and sorta checked-out, mentally.
Pumpkin, that's modern medicine. Advances that keep people alive who should have died a long time ago, back when they lost what made them people.
Now, your job is to stay sane enough so that when someone does come in that you actually can help, you're not so brain-dead that you can't function. For the love of God, what!?
It's just that, do you really think we should be talking about this in front of....
Her? She's dead.
Write this down, newbie: If you push around a stiff, nobody'll ask you to do anything.
You've been like a father to me.
Fair enough, you want some real advice? If they find out the nurses are doing your procedures for you, your ass'll be kicked outta here so quick, it'll make your head spin.
And there it is.
Have a terrific day.
I'm not really dead.
NEW_SCENE
Okay, Bambi, here's Mrs. Lendsner's tox-screen.
I wonder if Turk's having the same experience I am.
I am such a stud!
Probably not
This morning, I had my hands inside of a guy's chest. I couldn't even see them! I should not be allowed to do stuff like that. Whazzup.
And you weren't scared?
One way or another, everyone stops bleeding. That is so deep.
No it isn't.
It's a little deep.
Hey, we never got to talk about the apartment, I wanted to
T-man!
Word up, boy; how ya doin', man.
All right.
All right, Todd, J.D.; J.D., this is my man, Todd.
Oww!

And like that, I was back in high school. You see, surgical interns, they're all slice-'em-and-dice-'em. They're the jocks. Medical interns, we're trained to think about the body; diagnose, test. Medical interns, well....
Hey, you got a stain.
....We're the chess club.
NEW_SCENE
I just have bad gas. What are you testing me for?
We need to know if your gas could be harmful to others.
He's just scared. Talk to him.
Look, Mr. Bursky, I heard a systolic murmur in your heart, which is most likely nothing. But if you don't let me check you out, I'm gonna worry about you all day.
Then I'll do it. For you.
You're a good man.
NEW_SCENE
hospital interior, where J.D. is patiently standing behind the janitor, who is on a ladder, working on an elevator door.
I'm I'm waiting for someone.
The door is broke. Maybe the fifth time or so. It don't open.
Maybe there's a penny stuck in there?
Why a penny?
I dunno.
Did you stick a penny in there?
No. I was I was just making small talk.
If I find a penny in there, I'm taking you down.
NEW_SCENE
Welcome to rounds, kids. Let's
Elliot is the only thing keeping me from losing my mind. She's my dream girl.
...The necrosis and infected stool most likely indicate what, Dr...... Dorian?
I don't know!
Sir, I have no idea.
Dr. Reid, can you help him out?
I'd say it's superior mesenteric insufficiency.
That's my girl! Patient number two!
NEW_SCENE
Draining Mrs. Pratt's stomach fluid'll get my spirits back up.
Circles for you.
Shut up and do it.
Fantastic.
Just suck out the fluid with the giant needle.
I think this needle's too big. I'm gonna get a nurse.
Come on, man, learn by doing! Learn by doing.
Why couldn't I do that? I hated him at that moment.
Okay, uh, maybe the needle was just a little too big.
Oh, you think?
What's going on down there?
Nothing, ma'am, this is totally normal.
So, are you gonna are you gonna move your stuff in or what?
That's why I came by. I think it's better if we both branched out a little. What do you think?
Tell him you think that's stupid. Tell him you need him.
Yeah, I... I feel the same way.
NEW_SCENE
So, what's it like being a young, hot-shot doctor?
It's like... Did you ever go see a movie that everyone told you was great, and then because of all those expectations, you ended up totally disappointed?
Movies nowadays have too many special effects.
Yeah, that was pretty much my point.
NEW_SCENE

My first code. See, here's how it works: Someone's heart fails, they beep everyone. The first doctor in has to run the room, tell everyone what to do.... Basically decide if the patient lives or dies. What am I, crazy?
Agh! You chicken!
Don't worry about the patient, Turk was already there.... 'Learning by doing.'
Charge!
Clear!
Plus, it turns out, the guy was just sleeping; attached to a faulty monitor.
I thought we cared about each other....
Oh please, if you didn't want to sleep with me, you'd have done the same thing.
Well, I'll tell you one thing, the last thing in the world I wanna do is sleep wit'cha now!
Do me right here.
Okay.
See!
ARGH!
Right. Pass me a trach. kit.
Thanks.
Our date is is totally canceled!
Pff!
NEW_SCENE
I was sitting on the floor for two reasons. One, I tried to lock Elliot in that supply closet, and she kicked me hard. And two, the on call-room was locked.
Come on! I got, like, ten minutes to sleep!
Wait. Tell me if I'm going too fast, okay?
Lose the clothes.
I heard that Turk was gonna move in with Todd. I'm surprised that high-fiving freak isn't in there with him.
Damn, this is hot.
Nice.
Your turn.
No, I gotta get back. But, very nice.
Oh, hey, Bambi!
So, uhh, I'll call you, okay?
NEW_SCENE
Give me a big "ah".
Ah.
A big boy "ah".
Ahhh!
Turk practically had sex in the on-call room.
You realize, of course, I have no idea who Turk is.
...But, good for him. You see, Billy, it turns out that sex is life-affirming.
Now, whatta ya say, champ; you got a urine sample in there for me?
But I just did, five minutes ago.
I know you did, but here's the thing: I'd like you to take this cup, put it on the ground, close your eyes, and just go nuts! Whatta ya say!
Cool!
Atta boy! Go get 'em, champ!
Why are you here?
Seems like a good kid.
You're worried about being on-call tonight, aren't you.
Yeah.
Look, worst case scenario, you kill somebody, and that hangs over your head the rest of your life.

...But that is the absolute worst case scenario. Come on, newbie, look: Just have the nurses do all the stuff you're still too chicken to do, which I assume covers just about everything, and if you have a really rough admission
Call you?
No! I was gonna say go hide in the closet again!
Yee-ha! This is fun!
NEW_SCENE
Hey, nurse?
I'm a doctor, okay? The stethoscope, the beeper a doctor, got it?
Relax.
I just hate it. I hate the "darlin's" I hate the "sweethearts"...
You don't need to tell me how hard it is being a woman around here.
Well, you're certainly furthering the cause by wearing a thong to work and hooking up in the on-call room.
Word gets around.
You talk like that, do you even know my name?

I spend every second of my life either here, or taking care of my mom. So, yeah, maybe I needed a little closeness. I'm sure you never had a quickie at the club, right? Or snuck some skinny, flat-butted college boy up to your sorority room. And my thong? I happen to think it makes my ass look good. And some days, I need to feel good about something around here. And you judge me? Well, guess what, word does get around, Miss "Out For Herself", so you can dump on everyone here if you want; but you will not hurt me.
NEW_SCENE
Her name's Carla, by the way....
Ouch.
Yeah.... Carla....
NEW_SCENE

column2: THAT NIGHT	6 SECONDS BEFORE GOING ON CALL

column3: Interior The Doctors' Lounge.
Hey, Champ! First night on call starts soon, huh? Gosh, you must be excited.
Agghh!
You bet'cha.
Oh! About Mrs. Pratt.... I heard you wanted to put her on the hospital's transplant list. I just thought I'd recommend keeping her on dialysis a little while longer, maybe we'll get lucky!
No problem, sir.
Great! Have a ball...on call! A little poem for you.

column2: As he nervously enters the crowded hospital waiting room, David Gray's "Please Forgive Me" begins to play. We see scenes of J.D.'s experience on-call
column3: Wincing as he steadies a patient for a procedure. Filling out a chart for a man in drag. Checking the monitor of a sleeping patient, and taking a quick bite from the man's untouched food. Attempting to insert an IV, and having the nurse step in to help. Then finally settling down on the bed in the on-call room. As he flicks off the light, Carla steps in, turning it back on and summoning him.
Bambi, come on. Let's go.
I'll check on you every ten minutes, Mrs. Moreno, okay?
I need to see you in Mr. Bursky's room.
Are you flirting with me?
You are, aren't you!
He crashed. The attending thinks it was a pulmonary embolism.
No way anyone could have caught it. Anyhow, you have to pronounce him.
Why didn't anybody page me?
Could you just pronounce him so I can go home?
I'll never forget that moment, the way he looked exactly the same...only completely different. The shame that all I could think about was how hard this was for me.
Time of death 0200.
I just wanted to help people.
NEW_SCENE
The hardest part is how quickly you have to move on.
Don't worry, man. You're gonna be fine.
Hey. I lied before, man. I'm scared every second.
Really?
It's a good thing they make surgical masks, 'cause if they didn't, everyone would know that my face is like this the whole time...
Well, I think it's okay to be scared.
Well, I need you to tell me that every once in a while, man.
He needs me?
Anyway, I just came to check up on you; see how you're doing.
Ask him to move in again.
You know, Turk, the offer still stands if you wanna....
Dude, I already took the keys out' your bag.
I love you.
A Hospital Hallway.
And like that, I got a second wind.
I'm watching you....
How're you holding up?
Ah, there he is, my safety net.
I saw that you're still pushing to put Mrs. Pratt on the transplant list. Bad news, though, sport: she doesn't have the insurance to cover it.
Yeah, but she's, like, a second away from total renal failure.
Okay..... Uh, did you ask the Bursky family for permission to do an autopsy?
They're still in there with him, sir.
It's a teaching hospital, son, you gotta ask.
Just tell him you can't see Mr. Bursky again. He'll understand.
Sir, do you do you think I could skip just this one?
Why, sure, sport.
See? Every story needs a good guy.
In fact, why don't you just head on home. You look kinda tired.
I am pretty tired!

Dr. Dorian, do you not realize that you're nothing but a large pair of scrubs to me? For God's sake, the only reason I carry this chart around is so I can pretend to remember your damn names! Now look, if the patient has insurance, you treat them; if they don't, you show them the door.
And if somebody dies, you get the autopsy. You get it by rounds tomorrow morning, or I'll be scratching your name off my chart! Are we clear!?
Answer me!!!
Crystal clear.
Great, sport.
I don't get it, if he's the jerk, then who's the good guy?
Car accident, crashed in the elevator on the way up.
We gotta relieve the pressure in his chest. J.D., do it.
Oh God, no.
Look at me. You can do this.
And I believed him...
Chest-tube tray.
...You know, kinda.
Come on, baby, let's go; chop-chop.
You can do this. You have to do this.
J.D., cut him or lose him.
Okay, gimme the tube.
I can't get it through the pleura.
Well, don't be gentle, get it in there.
Okay, connect it, please, Carla.
Normal rhythm.
No way!
Eh? It's a piece of cake.
That's your patient.
You're leaving?
That's your patient, doctor.
G'head.
That's enough.
Sorry. It's a very big moment for me.
Mm-hmm.
NEW_SCENE
So, I guess that's it for now. Thirty-one hours, twelve minutes, and I am....
You're finally off?
Almost. I have one more really annoying thing I gotta do.
If you're talking about getting the Bursky autopsy, I already called the family for you. And they said fine, and to thank you, and I'm sorry. ...They didn't say that last part, I did.
The worst part was knowing, right then, that I could never forgive her.
I forgive her.
You see, I can't survive on my own.
I'm a dork. I'm a dork! I'm a dork. ...I'm a dork.
Even now, when I finally get to go home, in the back of my head, I'll know the hospital's still here, wide awake.
Bambi! Get out while you still can.
But what the hell. The most important thing is that I got through my first three days without looking like a complete idiot.
I'm the man.
NEW_SCENE
The human brain is remarkable. Once a day for nine years, I thought I lost my watch 'cause I can't remember which wrist it's on.
And yet, just after two weeks, all the little things that scared me at first are like second nature. Catheters, chest tubes, IVs...
...Everything has started to click.

column2: He reaches down to turn on his walkman, Leroy's "Good Time" begins to play. He looks around the activity of the hospital to see that everyone is working to the beat of the music playing in his ears. When his patient suddenly wakes up and mouths some of the words to the song, J.D. looks up, somewhat confused by the surreal moment. Dr. Kelso is now directly in front of him, exaggeratedly lip-sync'ing the chorus of the song
column3: Are you having a good time?
Are you? Because if you have time to listen to music, then I assume you have time to finish your paperwork!
...Having a good time....
Keep movin'.
NEW_SCENE
That workday started like every other.
Hospital, interior - Admissions Area.
How's it going?
I'm 37 years old, and I'm a janitor; how do you think it's going?
Now, there is nothing wrong with being a janitor.

Really? Thank you. You...you've turned my life around. I'm gonna have to go tell my janitor wife and all our janitor kids that life is worth living; and that comes straight from our hero, Dr. Whoozitz.... Dr. Nothin'.
No, seriously, come on. You can come over to my humble house and point out things that are cheap.
NEW_SCENE
Luckily, I had that night off to regroup.
Interior - the living room.
Your dog is creepy.
Aww... be nice to Rowdy. The guy we bought him from used to keep him in a box full of old hats.
Ew.
Okay, dude, why is she here all the time?
Just give her a chance, man.
Ohh... you want to hit that!
Nooo....
Yeah!
No. She's just a friend, man.
Yeah.
I think it's healthy hanging out with a girl without the ultimate goal being sex. You know?
I'm not following you.
Creepy.... I had a run-in with that Nurse Carla yesterday. She forgot to check out the stats on a patient, and then she gave me attitude about it.
What'd you tell on her, or something?
Who's responsible for this?
She is.
I don't remember... And why would you automatically assume it was my fault?
It would be a good point, except that Elliot puts her foot in her mouth. A lot. She can't really seem to stop.
Just because I occasionally say something stupid doesn't mean I'm in the hospital going door to door annoying people, like some crazed Jehovah's Witness.
Oh. You're not?
No.
But my mother is.
He's black, too. You should tease him about that.
NEW_SCENE
Me, I'm doing better with new people. Like Carla, for instance.
Hey, Bambi; that blond stick you hang out with? Tell her...Que se cuide la nalguita esa, porque si no le voy a tumbar todo el tinte rubio de la cabeza.
You might have to write that down for me.
And Dr. Cox, we've really connected.
I'm kinda like his protege.
I need to see his chart
Done. Copied. And Highlighted.
Unfortunately, Radar, I'm fresh out of gold stars. Multilobar pneumonia at 31...? How much does this guy smoke?
I dunno.
You realize, of course, it's your attention to detail that impresses me most. How many packs a day, genius.
Half a pack.
Oh, I'm sorry, I phrased the question wrong. How many packs a day... really.
Eleven.
Now you don't know where I'm coming from!
Two or three packs.
Well, let's hear it...
Oh, I don't smoke, so... zero packs.
What tests have you ordered?
Oh. I know, I was just totally kidding with you.
He was... We're all in on it.
I like Will. That actually makes this harder.
I ordered blood cultures, and a high-resolution CT.
What are you looking for?
Cancer.
When you say the word "cancer", every person reacts the same way.
Excellent.
Not like that.
There it is.
NEW_SCENE
I never really know what to say to Turk's stupid surgery buddies. But I'm getting better.
So....How's surgery?
It rocks... But my bedroom, that's where I really operate! Am I right? Come on, show Todd some love!
I hate showing Todd love.
Hey, Bambi. Why are you over here slumming with these scalpel jocks?
Please baby, this, here, is the V.I.P table.
Why don't you sit your fine self down?
Baby, this, here, is the V.I.P table...
I'm not really interested in her.
Yeah? Then maybe the Todd'll show that little biscuit some love!
Maybe he's a little interested.
Fine. Todd'll show himself some love.
NEW_SCENE
I'm thinking about asking Carla out today. What do you think?
I think the janitor's out to get me.
Wow. Thank you so much for your help. You know what? Why don't you be just a little bit more paranoid.
Wait, Turk.
That's him.
Nurses' Station.
Hi, how are you? Um... I need, uh, David Farr's chart?
We all need lots of things.
Great.
Uh, Dr. Kelso! You're the Chief of Medicine, is there a 'special' way to communicate with the nursing staff that I'm not getting?
Well, uh, sugar won't work because they're already so sweet.

Now, listen Dr...Whatever-the-hell-your-name-is, you tattled yesterday, I responded I feel closer to you than ever, really but the ramifications are yours. So don't try to drag me into your pathetic, whiny, little squabble with that God-awful bunch of malcontents. I hope you all kill each other! Have a great day, ladies.
I hate this place.
NEW_SCENE
Dr. Cox; I got, uh, Will's CT results back. No cancer! So, uh, what should I tell him?
I'd open with that.
Right, it's just, you know, he's headed down such a bad road, I thought you and I could talk to him....
When you really lock in with a mentor, you start to understand the meaning behind their words.
You do whatever you want.
Means, "Great idea!"
I'm, um, I'm just happy you haven't messed up yet today.
Means, "You're really coming along as a doctor."
Don't. Ever. Touch me.
Means, Don't ever touch him.
Just thought it was a nice moment.
NEW_SCENE
No, I don't wanna.
No, c'mon, c'mon, c'mon.
Carla...I...shouldn't have told Dr. Kelso on you.
No, you shouldn't have.
Ahhh, the comfortable silences.
But thank you for apologizing.
Okay, good!
I I just want to make one thing clear.
No, see, nothing needs to be clear.
I still think you were in the wrong. Checking for the statics is your job, and I need to know that you're going to take care of it.
a shot of Elliot's perspective from inside the grave. Carla, dressed in black, coldly flicks the ashes from a cigarette into the grave.
That's all I'm saying.
There. All better!
NEW_SCENE
So... yes! As of now, you have no signs of cancer.
Woo! Who rules? Will rules!
Uh, Will, it's important you realize this isn't great news.
Are you sure? 'Cause, that's how it first hit me.
Yeah, well, Will, you're on a slippery slope, man.
I had to scare him, but I had the sense he'd heard it all before. Luckily, part of being a doctor is your ability to improvise.
So, right now, the one thing that I want you to think about...
...How would you like to sound like this?
Let me see.
This is so cool!
No, it's not.
Bwiddy-bwiddy-bwiddy. Okay, doc.
It's not a toy.
Would you like to play a game?
Sometimes, if all you have is old words, all you can do is put them together and hope they say something new.
Look, man, you're a great patient. I like you enough to hope I never see you again. But, I promise you, if you keep smoking, you'll be back here. I bet my own life on that.
NEW_SCENE
Dr. Reid to room 402. Then down to 201. Then back up to room 403.
I'm nervous, man. Why am I nervous?
Todd's your wing-man, buddy. I will not leave your side. Hey, baby.
Keep moving, frat boy.
You got it.
Come on. Out with it.
Don't rush me!
I mean... You shouldn't be impatient with what I think is the opportunity of a lifetime.
Mmm. Okay, so I'm gonna go sit down because, you're so sexy, my knees are weak.
Really?
NEW_SCENE
Oh, Dr. Cox, I know I'm being annoying. But I I'm really getting used to talking to patients. I mean, this is why I became a doctor; right? Right?
I heard "I know I'm being annoying," and then...white noise.
Will, the pneumonia patient, I got him to quit smoking.
Forever?
Yuh-huh!
No "last one"? 'Cause the last ones are better than sex, trust me, I've had about a thousand of them.
Done forever. He swore to me. I just, I reached him! I reached him.
You're having a big day, there, Susan.
Private party.
NEW_SCENE
The Doctors' Lounge
Gotta get right back up on the horse.
Dr. Cox, about Will.

Oh, this woman is just fantastic. I mean, the breasts are probably fake, but, by God, those tears are real!

I need to know how we're going to fix this thing with Will.
Do you know what you've just done? You just lost all lap-dog privileges.
Excuse me?
No more walkies, no more treats, no more following me around the hospital.
I'm not your lap-dog.
Hey you, back there, what do we do with lap-dogs who can't behave in the house.
Make them stay outside?
That's right. You now have five seconds to get out of this room, otherwise I'm gonna start whacking you on the nose with this.
Don't laugh. This isn't a joke, newbie. Get. Out.
But I was thinking that
GO!

'Days of Our Lives'?

Come in.
Smells the food.

Look, Turk, I know that I don't always make the best first impression....Or second, for that matter. Anyway, I'd like us to be friends, and I thought, you know, maybe I could get to know you a bit better....
....See what you're about.... Uh....
For instance, when did you meet Morgan Freeman?
That's my mom.
I like her freckles!
Geez!!!
Rowdy, no!
So, I still can't figure out why Dr. Cox tore me a new one today.
Oh, man, enough already. He's a jerk.
He's a jerk.
The Hospital...
He's a jerk!
He's a jerk.
You're a jerk.

He's always like that.
Well, who really knows him? I mean, who does he hang out with here?
No one.
That must be lonely.
Take two Turks as needed, apply to sensitive area... Who wrote this?
Whazzup.... Oh, come on, Carla; give me one good reason why you won't go out with me.

Well, you're a surgeon. So, you've got the god-complex, the cockiness, the whole "married to the job" thing. You're cute, but you're very, very aware of it. You have no idea what I'm like, so all of your feelings for me are coming from down there. But most of all, I'm looking for the real thing; and you're nothing but a little boy who's not used to being told "No." So there's a bunch of reasons. Pick your favorite.
I'd go with the "god-complex".
But it's hard to choose, you know, they're all so good.
NEW_SCENE
A hospital is a tricky place. I mean, it's very cliquey, and you have to watch what you say. It's a lot like high school.

column2: Dr. Kelso as the principal, and the nurses as the cheerleaders watch Elliot walking past the tables in full "geek" regalia
column3: horn-rim glasses, oral retainer, band uniform. Not watching where she's going, Elliot trips and spills her tray of food all over the floor. The nurses/cheerleaders, surgeons/jocks, and other "students" laugh at her.
I'd like to think that if I didn't have somewhere else to be that I'd gone and sat with her. But, you see, tonight, there's somebody else I have to take care of.

J.D., in casual clothes, with a 6-pack in hand, approaching the door of an apartment. He rings the bell. The door opens to reveal Dr. Cox. The sounds of a televised sporting event can be heard from inside the apartment.

I know that watching Will slowly kill himself hurts you, too. That's even harder if you don't have anyone to talk about it with. So, when I got off work, I figured you know I was gonna pick up a few cold ones, right, and then maybe you and I, we'll we'll talk it out, we'll just break the whole thing down. Right? What do you say to that?
NEW_SCENE
I'm sick of this, everyone keeps ignoring me. I'm like a damn plague around here.
Please, don't look back at me when you're talking.
Oh, uh, Dr. Reid. I just wanted to say you're out of my dog house. That was a great catch on that patient with meningoccocus.
Well, that actually wasn't me, sir. Carla noticed the rash on his legs.
Well, that's fascinating. You could have fallen back into my good graces, and instead you passed the credit on to a nurse.
How noble! I'll tell you what, I'll get the cafeteria staff to write "Was it worth it?" on a big cake for you!
Nurses' Station.... So this is the Nurses' Station....
NEW_SCENE
Do you think I've damaged the ligaments?
I don't care.
Now, can I count on you to never drop by here ever again, or should I just go ahead and move?
Oh, you can't leave a place with this much warmth. I especially love the shelf filled with personal photos of your friends and family.
A very sterile-looking glass shelf with several "blank" pieces of modern art.
Okay, if he comes at you, just try and roll out the door.

Well, actually, you have a point. I guess watching the game by yourself with a scotch isn't, really, the only way to watch a game, huh. I don't know. I just, I've always thought of needing people as a sign of weakness.
It's not.
Then, would you stay... and watch the game with me? Maybe have a slice of pizza?
Of course I will.
I can braid your hair.
No, I know the couch isn't very deep, but we can move the back cushion... and spoon.
Hey, guys, whatta ya say. Beer and chips in the back.
Just ignore them. Will you tell me the answer to this question: Do you want to be the big spoon, or the little spoon?
NEW_SCENE
I'm telling ya, Kelso didn't even ask, and she gave you full credit.
I don't care. Too little, too late. Plus, I know why you're really here. So, I'm gonna park myself right here in the "V.I.P section," so you can give me what'cha got.

I was gonna tell you how I busted J.D.'s chops the other day for wanting to be friends with a girl. And now I find it so amazing to see how strong you are, how well you carry yourself, how I'd give anything just to wake up in the morning and watch you read the paper. But instead, I think you should hop off your broom for a second, try and remember what it was like when you first started here, and give Elliot a break. Because she may be a chore, but she is a good person. Your ass is especially fine today.
Pick me up tomorrow at seven.
She's not the only one that can do a speech. I can do a speech.
NEW_SCENE
You are to return that umbrella to me at the hospital, not here, is that clear?
Hey, newbie. You know what your problem is?
My bones hurt?

You were gonna, what, rescue me from loneliness with a three-dollar six-pack of light beer? It turns out, you can't save people from themselves, newbie. We just treat 'em. You treat that kid with a respiratory problem, and when he comes back with cancer, go ahead and treat that, too.
Well, thanks for the pick-me-up!

Hey! Smokers, drinkers, druggies, fatties, whatever. All I'm saying is that if you keep living and dying on whether or not a person changes, well... you're not gonna make it as a doctor, that's all. Now... come here and gimme a hug.
It's okay. Come here...Come here.
Aw, get outta here! And take this piss-water with you. It's embarrassing to have it here.
I'll drink it!
Eh! I'll take the beer. You beat it.
NEW_SCENE
Go apologize.
No, I don't wanna.
Okay, come on, come on, come on. Just do it really fast, like a Band-Aid.
Here, I wrote out the pharmacy renewals on all your patients.
Wow. Great! Hey, you know what else would be really helpful...
I think the one thing we never stop looking for is acceptance.
Thank you, Carla.
You're welcome.
Acceptance of our own shortcomings...
So, when's the baby due?
What baby?
...Acceptance that some things are gonna be what they're gonna be.
This is a strange resort, man. I mean, this wheelchair service is great, but that suite I rented... there's another person in it. And for some reason, the bellhop gave me an enema.
Yeah... he's new here.
So... anything you wanna say?
You know it all, man.
Still, I hated Will a little....
...'Cause, thanks to him, I started to look at all the people who were important to me in terms of what will probably kill them.
Heart Disease...
Liver disease...
Somebody choking her...
I dunno... Probably stress.
Say anything else to him?
Nope.
But you wanted to.
Yeah, but you told me not
Geez, J.D., would you be a man? Lookit, if you can't stick to your convictions, you'll never make it as a doctor.
I can't believe your head exploded. If your head explodes, you'll never make it as a doctor. I mean, come on, you look ridiculous.
NEW_SCENE
The Hospital, interior a darkened corridor.
NEW_SCENE

I don't know why I came to watch Turk in surgery when I could've caught a few minutes of sleep. I guess I just haven't seen much of my best friend, lately. Still, it's not like I'm desperate or anything.
Look, I've been attending here for three years. What makes you think you know better?
In my gut, I know I'm right.
We need to make this decision now!
Fine, then, it's on you.
Yes, it is! Nurse Erasure!
Yes, doctor.
I hate this song!
Me too, man. Me too.

The Hospital, night-time a private patient's room.
It's weird, but a hospital room can actually be a romantic place. Maybe it's the soft green glow of a heart monitor, or the way the moonlight reflects off a bedpan....
Our shifts keep overlapping on Friday nights.
It's the closest thing I've had to a date, recently.
Well, I had a great time tonight.
Oh, yeah, me too. So... can I page you?
You better. And don't do the whole two-day waiting thing.
Oh, baby, I don't play by the rules.

Elliot hauls off and slaps J.D. hard.

J.D. looks at Elliot, perplexed

In wedding garb, Elliot and J.D. stand together, grinning. Elliot shows off her gigantic ring to the camera before giving J.D. an exuberant kiss.
J.D. and Elliot lie in bed, sweaty and panting.
Elliot and a brunette kiss. They part and the camera pulls back to reveal them in bed, just as J.D. sits up between them, looking like he's won the lottery.

I'll see ya.

Legally, there's a huge difference. When you stitch a patient, wind up sewing a sheet to him, that's an accident. When he tries getting up, the whole gurney collapses, breaking his front teeth, that's a lawsuit. Say it with me: Accident. Lawsuit.
Accident. Lawsuit.
So, what is it, sweetheart?
It's that, it's the sweetheart thing. It just doesn't hit me right. I'm a doctor, and it seems sort of... disrespectful.
Oh? I've always called the young men "sport" and the young women "sweetheart".
But, you called Becky "sport".
Oh... Well, I am so sorry.... Sport.
It must be one of those bad habits I've developed after working in the medical field for over thirty years.
Th-thirty years? But... you look so young!
NEW_SCENE
It's never easy to see a patient that's getting worse instead of better. In fact, that's kind of the opposite of what we're going for.
I don't get it, he was fine last night. Now he's diaphoretic, he's in and out of consciousness. He might even be septic.
Well, we won't know anything until the lab gets his blood-work back.
If he's septic, there's a chance they'll have to reopen this guy. 'Course, there's also a chance he could die.
I've seen this before. Gauze, sponges some young surgeon left something in this man.
Noo. No. I know the guy that closed, he'd never be that careless.
'Kay, uh... Excuse me, sorry; has anyone seen my keys? No? Okay, how about my wallet? Anyone?
I've never seen that before.
Oh, baby, please... give a little respect... to me.

....Oh, baby refrain from breaking my heart. I'm so in love with

Sweetie, you have to be a minority sidekick in a bad movie to pull that off. You know what I'm talking about, right?
Explain it to this man, please.

...And then you give a lot of attitude. That's how it works. But if you're not from there, you don't understand, so I'm not gonna even 'axe' you

Thank you very much.

Hi, how are ya? I have a quick legal question. What if, hypothetically
Oh, God, you killed somebody!
Noooo!

Look, if you know about something, by not reporting it you're every bit as culpable. Now, is there anything that you'd like to tell me?
Why am I protecting Turk when he can't even give me five seconds of his time?
Anything at all?
Tell him.

Dr. Cox.
I'm hoping, for your sake, there's another Dr. Cox sitting right behind me.
I feel stupid, but, sending me to Kelso like that well, I'm not sure, exactly, what you were trying to teach me.
The value and this is important of leaving me alone.
I think we both know there was a little more to it than that.
No, no, no, there's not! Look...

I want you to spread the word, missy I've. Had. Enough. The next whiny intern that comes in here looking to me for a cookie and a hug, I swear to Aisha, I'm going to hurt them. And you, you neurotic, one-woman freak-show, take your "Blah-blah" to the blah-blah-ologist. Because if you are so stupid as to confront the Chief of Medicine over some quasi-offensive endearment, then you've just got to go ahead and replace the captain of your brainship, because he's drunk at the wheel.
You're right. I need to learn to pick my battles! Thank you, sir.

Twice!

Look, Turk....
Come on, man; you know I always got your back.
I know.

Hello? I'm the doctor!
I'm...I'm...I'm the doctor.

I paged Dr. Cox and he should be here any second.

...no muy bien.

One, two, three
So should I continue with the Hep
It's really important that you let me get to ten.
Well, I just thought

But if you ever do wanna know my opinion, rest assured it will always be that you're an incredible pain and that every time I see your kew-pie-doll face, it just makes me wanna pick you up and shake you until all the hours of my life that you've wasted...fall out. Now laugh.
What?
Laugh so that she doesn't think I'm yelling at you.
Ohh!... How fun was that!

column2: He takes it from J.D. and begins reading. J.D. stands waiting, his eyes locked on the Janitor, who begins mouthing something at him. J.D. puts his hand to his ear and mouths back "What?" So, the Janitor repeats, this time with hand motions
column3: he points to himself "I'm" then he makes a walking motion "going" he holds up two fingers "to" he wrings an imaginary neck "kill" and he points at J.D. "you."
Why?
We'll put her on diuretics.

These labs don't look good; I think it's time she got started on dialysis.

What's that?
Find her.

Freedom!!!
Went to the park?

'Niners-Cowboys, Joe Montana to Dwight Clarke deep in the end-zone, zero time left. Kid, please, don't insult me.

Mrs. Tanner....
Oh, here's the party.

Speaking of Heparin, have you slept with Turk yet?

I like to wait. I like a guy to want it so bad he basically thinks he isn't gonna get it ever.
Then when he's lost the will to live, that's when I jump him.
So, how long does that usually

I like to use sex as an ice-breaker.
Ah. And how's that working out for you?

I've got a ton of bricks for Dr. Dorian?
Could I get that pen back?

Dracula From Houston plays again as Elliot and Carla stare at Mrs. Guerrero's monitor; Turk looks at David on the table, then to Dr. Wen, who gives a slight nod; J.D. continues to stare at Mrs. Tanner in disbelief.

But what about our duty as doctors to do everything in our power to help pe

'What about our duty as doctors?' Look. This has nothing to do with the patient it's all about you. You are afraid of death, and you can't be. You're in medicine, you gotta accept the fact that everything we do here everything is a stall. We're just trying to keep the game going; that's it. But, ultimately, it always ends up the same way.

Gonenn kan kurai Kyoto ni sunnde imashita.

The Darkened Doctor's Lounge.

What the hell happened to "I'll be right back"? I can't believe I actually started to think I've been wrong about you. That woman needs her doctor to tell her something, anything, and you run away? Are you even gonna look at me?

Oh, I've been trying to decide what drink to get. I've been standing here trying to choose between cherry soda and, uh, ginger ale. And you know what? It's a toss-up. I mean, either way I get a cold drink, right? And it would be almost impossible for me to kill someone with this decision, but... I still can't make it. I think I'm in trouble here.

Look, I don't think these kinds of decisions are easy for anyone. And if it's any consolation, one of the reasons I never liked you is because you're already better at this than most of the doctors that come through here; and to be honest, I kinda liked being the only smart, strong chick in the joint.
You sort of just complimented me.
Little bit.
Okay, I'm gonna have a ginger ale.

Okay.
Here we go.

Done.

You have had an amazing life.
Good, then we agree. Now, aren't there other patients you need to be seeing?

So, with your precious free time, you've been sitting in a hospital room talking to an old lady. What about your list? How many of those things have you done? For that matter, how many times have you sat in the grass and done nothing, hm?
You need to start taking some time for yourself, young man. Promise me you'll do that.
I will.

Turk told me.

Good. Because what I want is for this to be a real relationship. I want us to know each other better than we know ourselves.
Wow.
That's right "wow."
So if you really want me 'daily and nightly and ever so rightly'...
That sounds like something you'd say.
...Show me that you know me.
So, anyway, I think you should let the kid meet the ladies.

Looks like word gets around.

It took me, like, three hours to realize who

So, listen; I've scheduled an appendectomy for you later. Just make sure you're good on potassium.
Sir, I got so much potassium, it's coming out of my 'assium'! You know what I mean?
NEW_SCENE
See, what I did was I took 'potassium', and...I dropped the first three letters.... Made a doodie joke.
Funny stuff.
Looks like he bought it.
Excuse me?
So you got a little stage-fright, it's no big deal. Happened to me once.
Really?
I'll be more than glad to tell you what a lot of doctors do to relieve the stress: Just take a little trip to "Palmdale."
What?
Okay give yourself the old "low-five."
I'm not getting it.
Physician, love thyself.
Are you talkin' about down-town, Lester Brown?
Lowers the heart-rate, releases the endorphins, it's basic physiology.
Okay, you almost had me.
You're not serious.
Yes, I am.
No, you're not.
Yes.
No.
Huh. Okay.
Nobody hurts Carla and gets way with it.
Who's Carla?
I was talkin' to myself; don't eavesdrop.
This kid doesn't leave, I'm gonna kill him.
Now, if you leave, I'll know you were eavesdropping I'll just go ahead and kill you, anyway.
Stay. Good girl.
NEW_SCENE
Tick-tock, Clarice.
Dr. Kelso's talk helped me figure out what I had to do.
Hey, good timing. Gimme a hand with this foley cath., will ya?
Oh, you got it.
Whether or not Nick knew how petty and jealous and competitive I'd been, I still felt like I needed to step up, lay it out there, and apologize like a man.
We cool?
Yeah.
Besides, even if I was the star for a little while, he's the man now.
This belongs to you.
Oh, thanks a lot, man.
Can you grab me some more tape?
Oh, sure.
Once you line up behind a truly strong leader, everyone picks up their game.
We need to get the results of this urine sample.
We began to function like a well-oiled machine.
Hey, Nick, I got the results back from the, uh.... Nick?
His blood cultures don't look good at all.
No problem.
NEW_SCENE
Listen, I was thinking about what happened earlier, and.... Anyway...uh, here.
Wow. You finally dug deep down in your heart and came up with a muffin!
That's store-bought, sister. There's blueberries in there the size of your fist.
I shouldn't have dragged you into it, anyway. You don't even know Turk.
Actually, I met him today. We had a terrific chat.
Oh, give the man a hand. That's just terrific work. You know darn well that felt good. And you're feeling better about yourself, now, aren'cha?
Real nice guy.
It's hard letting yourself be vulnerable with someone, you know?
Oh, just eat the damn muffin, would ya, please?
NEW_SCENE
You know what? Even though I'm on-call tonight, I'm not gonna let the bad stuff in anymore. I'm not gonna let myself get overwhelmed.
What?
Well, it's just that, Friday night, when you had people over, you locked yourself in your room because we brought the wrong chips.
Look at me. That was the old Elliot.
Hey, can you help me find Dr. Murdoch? Peter's parents are here and he's not answering his page.
Sure. You know, Elliot's not gonna let herself be overwhelmed anymore.
She's been drinking!
NEW_SCENE
Carla? Wow. You look great.
You're not messing with me, right?
No. But I'd like to.
Turk bought me this dress, out of the blue. I guess he knew I'd love it.

Oh. Look, Carla. Back when I was an intern, I remember the pressure being so insane that the only way I could get by was to race home and, even though my wife was already asleep, I'd gently wake her, look her in the eyes, and then I'd passive-aggressively torture her until she packed a bag and went to her mom's place for the week.
Does that...help?
Like a big hug with words.
Hey! The point is that just 'cause a guy has problems expressing himself, that doesn't mean he doesn't need...you.
Oh, boy. Women so don't get me... it's not even funny!
It's mind-boggling, quite frankly, It the whole thing...is...stunning.
NEW_SCENE
The point is, is that it's the scrubs, right? Because, in jeans, my butt is a force to be reckoned with.
Hey. We were just looking for you.
Nick! Touch my butt, please? ...Hey, you all right?

That kid is eventually gonna die. Whether it's today, or tomorrow, or a month from now. There's nothing I can do; nothing works. Now his parents want to talk to me, what am I supposed to tell them "Peter lived a good, long seven years"? Seven years, man!
It's not fair. I hate this place. I hate this job
Nick, it's not your fault
I can't do it anymore. I I'm done...I'm done...I'm done.
The scariest thing was that I thought he was stronger than all of us. But maybe it's not about being the best. Maybe it's about finding the little things that get you through the day.
Whether it's the support of someone close to you...
...or letting yourself feel overwhelmed...
Okay....
...if only for a moment.
Or being selfless every once in a while.
I don't know.
I guess, in the end, it's about surviving...
...any way you can.
See you tomorrow.
Whoa!
You're stupid.
That's it?
Give it time, it'll eat at ya.
Am I stupid?
Yeah, little bit.
Damn him!
NEW_SCENE
A Street Downtown Day
One of the best things about my friendship with Turk is that we're always challenging each other to try new things.
I can't believe we're going to a strip club for lunch.
Oh, don't even think about it that way. This is just a nice place to buy a burger that's a short, convenient two-and-a-half-mile walk away from the hospital.

column2: Now within sight of the club, they stop when they notice a small group of people marching around outside the front doors with signs in their hands. As one, they chant
column3: No skin! We all win!! No skin! We all win!!
Let's get outta here before we end up on the 6 o'clock news.
Excuse me, are you gentleman visiting the club?
No! ...We're here protesting.
I'm worried about the kids.
So what's that in your pocket?
Oh, this is just, um, it's thirty-eight dollars in singles....
I-I bought a newspaper, and this is the change from my forty.
Neil!
Sir!
No pulse.
Starting CPR.
Call an ambulance!
NEW_SCENE
Coming to you live as two young doctors are trying to resuscitate my cameraman.
Well, maybe I'm biased but, to me, every doctor here at Sacred Heart is a hero. Does that mean I'm a hero? I don't know... Ahh! There's my Dynamic Duo!
Dr. Dorian! Dr. Turk!
Holy inferiority complex, Batman! How low is my self-esteem that I'm the sidekick in my own fantasy!?
It could be worse, Robin. You could be Alfred, the Butler.
Damn you...sir.
Life in a hospital moves so fast. One second you're a hero, the next, you're obsessing about intern evaluations.
Who cares? It's only a grade.
Really, what'd you get?
An A-plus. But, then I turned on the water-works and the resident changed it to an A-plus-plus.
It's a proud day for women everywhere.
What are you worried about? With the whole "hero" thing, whoever evaluates you is gonna give you a gold star.

Listen, Super Girl: I'm gonna break you down into so many little pieces that my grandmother, who can do a thousand-piece puzzle of clear-blue sky in less than an hour, will never be able to finish putting you back together again. Even if she does go back in time to when her vision was perfect.
Somehow, I doubt it.
NEW_SCENE
The Hospital, Exterior Day
Interior The Doctor's Lounge
Before you deny that you like looking at strange naked women again I should remind you that when you stay at my place, it's not a hotel; the movie titles do come up on the bill.
I'm sticking with we were protesting.
Outraged and disgusted.
You should take Bambi out tonight; maybe with all the hype, you can finally get him a girl.
Okay. Who hasn't bought us drinks, yet?
It could happen!
Don't wait up for me tonight, okay?
Okay.
So, do you want to get drunk and beg me to have sex with you now, or do you wanna wait till 2 o'clock tonight?
Let's wait.
Cool.
You know, I'm off tonight. Um, what are you doing, Carla?
I'm just...having dinner with a friend.
Oh, man; this is so uncomfortable. She's not gonna get the invite.
Just hold your breath until it's over.
You could take Elliot with you?
Great. I can't wait.
Have a good time tonight!
NEW_SCENE
Did you lose something?
No, why? Did you take something?
No.
What'd you take?
Nothing.
What'd you take.
Newbie! Come!
Now that I think about it, I'm psyched to have Dr. Cox do my evaluation. It'll give me a chance to finally see what he truly thinks of me.
Look, Doogie, I'm up to my cha-chas in busy work, so I'm gonna go ahead and take a rain-check on your report card just have you do it yourself.
You didn't even fill out my name.
Well, now, I think it's John, or Jimmy, or jeh , or ehnn...
Oh, gosh, it's in the 'J' family; but if you get in trouble, just ask the nurses for help.
NEW_SCENE
Sir, I've been the hospital's legal counsel for... well, let's just say when I started, I had hair....
...And a wife and family.... The point is, I'll never get a raise without the support of senior staff like yourself.
Can't do it.
Well, you did what you could!
Dr. Dorian, how are you?
Well, sir, these evaluations...

It's just a pleasantry, sport; let's keep it moving. Listen, I've been thinking, with all the publicity you and your friend have been getting, it would be silly not to milk it a little bit see if we can't promote the hospital. What do you say?
Okay, whose breasts haven't I signed yet?
It could happen!
Excuse me?
Anything for the hospital, sir!
So, what are we doing tonight?
Oh...go out to dinner, I guess.
Ooh, dinner! Where're we gonna eat?
Oh, I don't know, some restaurant.
Mmm! Some restaurant!
Be honest, um, does this look, uh, "hip" enough?
Since when are khakis, a pink shirt, and a neckerchief not hip?
True.
Hey!
Hi!
Hey, Darryl.
Um, I have to make a quick call. So, Patricia, Darryl, this is Elliot.
Hi!
Nice to meet you.
Nice to meet you, too.
I'm gonna get out of here, all right?
Okay. Thanks for the ride.
Oooh, someone's a cradle-robber!
Darryl's my son.
Oh, come on, the only way he could be your son is if you had him when you were, like, fifteen.
Fourteen.
Oh.... I was close!
Listen, I'm really sorry, that was my mom I'm gonna have to cancel.
NEW_SCENE
I can't evaluate myself.
Would you describe me as 'warm', 'professional', or both?
I describe you as: I'm on my lunch.
I dunno whether to be easy or hard on myself. I mean, either way
Can't you see I'm watching my stories?
Dr. Cox? Have you been here the whole time?
No; I just came in through the couch door. Move.
But I thought you said you were too busy to do my evaluation?
I am. Didn't her daddy sell the coal mine?
Contract didn't stick.
Ohhh. That's interesting.
Uhh-huh.
Mmm-hmm.
NEW_SCENE
'Kay, well, we're almost ready. Is there anything you want to say before we get started?

Yeah, I got something to say to Dr. Cox! I'm gonna give you the best damn evaluation that you ever did see! And this Friday, at the steel-cage mmmedi-slam, I'm gonna give you a physical that you ain't never gonna forget! I'm gonna probe ya 'cause I'm The Intern!!!
Nothing! Okay, I'll be right back.
She is ta-haasty. Watch me work a little cat-and-mouse game with her.
She's married to the sound-man, bud. And that little thing that's clipped to your collar, that's a microphone.
I am so sorry.... And I love ZZ Top.
I'm not looking forward to this.
Okay, we're rolling. So, how is my cameraman doing?
Well, good enough that he asked me for mouth-to-mouth again!
Dr. Turk, um, are there any specific challenges being a young black doctor in an inner-city hospital?
...My nieces and nephews really look up to me...
I'm I'm sorry, I really want to hear this. Is it possible to turn the volume just a little?
That's as high as it goes.
Elliot.
Hi! Listen, let me tell you what happened....
Elliot! ... Damn.
NEW_SCENE
When I saw that it was missing, did you not think I'd come to you?
I don't know what you're talking about.
Oh. So you're gonna play it that way, huh? Touche.
I, uh, finished my evaluation.
Oh, great. I thought it was gonna take you a little longer, so the marching band won't be here until this evening.
Enjoy. I think you'll find it's a good read.
Hey, Newbie. This thing actually does matter, so tell me, were you completely honest with yourself?
Well, yeah....
Say it right into the camera, there, hotshot. Now, you can have this thing back anytime you want. You're gonna have to bark like a dog, though.
I'm I'm not...gonna bark like a
It's your call.
Woof!
Good boy.
NEW_SCENE
At the very least, I'm gonna end today on a good note.
Yo, I got something to show you.
This isn't one of those uncomfortable moments that'll change our friendship, is it?
No, no, no! You're going to like it!
Good. 'Cause I need some good news, man. Can you believe that newslady? "What's it like to be a black doctor?"
I just wish this was over.
Why have we stopped?
Roll 'em up.... Roll 'em up.
NEW_SCENE
Turk and J.D.'s Apartment, exterior Night
What makes you think I'd wanna be part of this, J.D.?
I don't know! Kelso said it would make us role models. I guess I just assumed that
Yeah, everybody assumes that I'm a good athlete, or or or that I grew up poor, or that I love 'Sanford and Son'.
But you do love 'Sanford and Son'.... We both do.
Bum-bum-bwa-dum. Bum-bum-bwa-dum-bwa-dum-bum.
Bum-bum-bwa-dum.
That's what I'm talkin' about.
The Center of the Living Room A Few Moments Later

Listen, if Dr. Kelso wants me to be a "role model" for the community because I'm a great doctor, then that's great, and I will sign on the dotted line. But that's not what this is about. All my life, I've been singled out because I'm black.
But I didn't even enter the contest!
Shh. Smile for the picture.
Remember our college brochures?
So what, they put you on the cover.
Twice?
Ohh? Ohh!
Come on, it's different this time. Now it's both of us.
One of the promotional posters...
A park bench...
Yet another poster, plastered on a wall of the hospital...
You can still see my hand on your shoulder.
And that's when I realized, I'm not gonna let people take advantage of me anymore.
Look, this is so unfair, you're supposed to do my evaluation not me. And, you know what? You're gonna do it, buddy-boy.
Buddy-boy? Why...I...oughtta....
I'm serious.
Relax, Newbie. It's just an evaluation; it should be easy.
Well, if it's that easy, then it won't take you that long to do it.
All right, well, don't you worry about it another minute, there, Newbie. I'll evaluate you, I'll evaluate the hell right outta ya.
When?
Oh, just the second I get off work.
Fine!
Fine!
Great!
Great!
Here it is.
You get off, like, six-ish, er...?
Oh, danger. Ohh, ohhh!
NEW_SCENE
You know, you're gonna have to see her eventually.
No I don't; 'cause I know the layout to the air-duct system here like the back of my hand.
Of course I'm gonna have to see her again!
So, what, this is the part where all of a sudden it's my fault?
Turk, if you could have seen the look on her face I'm telling you, if I think about it again, it's gonna make me cry.
What am I gonna do?
It's simple: just keep doing what you're doing. Eventually she'll quit and move.
Why am I even talking to you?
What?
You're such a guy. You can't even begin to understand something this deep on any kind of real emotional level.
Hey, Turk. Look, I'm really sorry about the whole poster thing. It was racially insensitive of me; I should have been more aware of your feelings before I went ahead and spoke for you.
It's okay; your intentions were good, and there's never been an issue of race between us. Since the day I met you, you've been nothing but a friend to me.
I love you, man.
Hit me one.
Keep it real!
Yeah, we've got some things to work out, but, we'll get there... We'll get there.
NEW_SCENE

...Sure, it hurts. You know what? I'm not gonna wallow in self pity. Right after work, I'm gonna go straight downtown and just...tear it up, you know? Maybe I'll have a cigarette; just get a little crazy and head wherever the night takes me.
What's that, now?
Thanks so much!
TAXI!
Hey, baby! How much?
Hey! Where're you go ? Don't go away mad!
Get me the hell out of here! Hurry!
NEW_SCENE
Here's what we're gonna do: I'm gonna leave the cart...in the closet, I'm gonna leave the closet unlocked. If, by magic, it should happen to reappear, I won't ask any questions.
I don't even know what 'it' is.
Then why take it?
NEW_SCENE
Well, if it isn't Dr. Turk, the friendly face of Sacred Heart.
Yeah.... Dr. Kelso, um, about these posters , they're kind of making me uncomfortable.
Oh, I'm so sorry. I didn't realize you felt that way. Well, here's what I'm gonna do: I'm gonna leave 'em up.
I can live with that. Or, I can sue you.

Dr. Turk, you are an employee, here. I can advertise however I wish. I can use your image, your name, I can manufacture tiny little Dr. Turk action figures it'll cost $12.95, and when you pull the string it'll say, "I don't like these posters of me!" Isn't that right, Ted?
Oh, definitely, sir.
Of course, you'd certainly be vulnerable from a legal standpoint.
How vulnerable?
Sir, that lawsuit would be over so quickly, I'd advise you to bring cab fare to the courthouse, since Dr. Turk will be driving your Beemer home to his place.
Hippie!
God, that felt good!
Who's the man?
Is it me?
Damn right, it's you!
Oh.
Right, man!
It's me!
Various hospital walls...
NEW_SCENE
Elliot, there's no excuse for what I did.
No, there's not.
Are we done?
I'm really sorry.
Don't be. If I was going out with my friend, I wouldn't invite you.
Who am I kidding. Yes, I would, and she'd probably like you better and neither one of you would ever talk to me again.
Look, I only did it because I hadn't seen Patricia in a long time.
Carla, you only did it 'cause I don't fit in with you and your friend. It's no surprise, it's not like I've ever really fit in anywhere.
Carla, your friend Patricia's here. There's a little problem with her son.
Why so sad, Marshmallow?
NEW_SCENE
Stay calm, stay calm, stay calm. Oh, good; he's not here.
Dr. Cox?
It's time. Sit down.
Now, what do you want me to say? That you're great? That you're raising the bar for interns everywhere?
I'm cool with that.

I'm not gonna say that. You're okay. You might be better than that someday; but right now, all I see is a guy who's so worried about what everybody else thinks of him that he has no real belief in himself.
I mean, did you even wonder why I told you to do your own evaluation?
I-I can't think of a safe answer. I just figured

Clam up! I wanted you to think about yourself and I mean really think. What are you good at? What do you suck at? And then I wanted you to put it down on paper. And not so I could see it, and not so anybody else could see it, but so that you could see it. Because, ultimately, you don't have to answer to me, and you don't have to answer to Kelso, you don't even have to answer to your patients, for God's sake! You only have to answer to one guy, Newbie, and that's you!
There. You. Are.... Evaluated.
Now get the hell outta my sight. You honest-to-God get me so angry, I'm afraid I just might hurt myself.
NEW_SCENE
So, what are you, one of the male nurses?
No, actually, I'm a surgeon. I'm doing this as a favor for Carla.
Yeah, Carla is fine.
What's she doin' wit' you?
Slummin' a little, God bless her heart. So, this is a knife cut, hey?
Yeah, it's cool.
See this right here? Pinched it in a door two stitches!
Oh, man, yeah, yeah, you hard-core, man.
Hell, yeah!
Look, Darryl's gonna be fine. But I'm worried about you; you're a little upset, so I'm gonna set you up in a room with some fluids, maybe give you a Valium, okay?
Elliot, thank you.
Hey, there you are.
Oh, honey.
Elliot, you're coming, right?
In a sec.
You all right?
Yes.
It's funny how our perceptions can be so off....
Hot cocoa, sweetie?
Thanks.
Anytime.
...Like, when you're searching for a place to fit in, and you don't even realize you've been there the whole time.
Or how a bunch of posters can't turn you into a role model if you've already been one for years.
Hell yeah!
Of course, in my case, I knew exactly where I stood. And it didn't feel that good.

I would like to make special mention of one intern here: John Dorian. Smart kid, he's extremely confident, and his enthusiasm and his determination to always be better is something I see in him 24 hours a day. He cares. Probably cares too much. But he's definitely somebody you don't want to lose.
Now, if you have any questions, uh...well, I could give a crap; I'm goin' home. You all get paid way too much for doing nothing, anyway.
NEW_SCENE
Oh, good, Newbie you found a specialty.
Nah.... I just dropped my...pen!
Well, look what magically found its way back home.
What, your window cleaner?
No. Ammonia. This is window cleaner, right, uh....
Why!?
Now that's just bad luck.
NEW_SCENE
As a first year intern you have very little free time. So when you finally have a night off, it's important that you do something constructive with it.
Hey! Hey! Over here man!
Hey man how's it goin?
I have no idea who you are.
What up dude!
Hey wait a second he's dating Carla. This is not good.
First of all I already told her I got a girlfriend. Second you just put your bare lips on my ear.
How's it goin I'm-
J.D., I know. He won't stop talking about you. I'm Jennifer.
Mmm Jennifer.
Do you really spend every day saving children's lives.
Tell the nice lady.
I do what I can.
It's on, it's on, it's on, it's on, it's on!
I know two things about bars, one they're always packed the week of Thanksgiving and two put a beer in my hand and I'm Mr. Smooth.
I was laughing so hard milk was coming out of my nose.
Well, I once tripped over an I.V. and blood shot over everyone! Er uh a little got on my nose Every damn day saving those children!
Who wants margaritas? Dude, less blood more fruity drinks.
Right.
That's the thing about Turk he hasn't changed a bit since college. He's still the same goofball who tells me how to be cooler.
Dude, this girl's pretty hot, so try not to blow it. Okay?
Why do you say that?
Because you're like a 24 hour convenience store. You never close.
That sounds like a Fat Albert joke.
Don't worry about it man I feel good tonight, you know what I'm saying?. Except for this stabbing pain in my side.
So he was up all night with a high fever, cramping and crying.
Dude!
Oh my bad not crying. Punching the wall all manly and angry like. You know what I mean?
Poor Bambi. Don't worry Carla will take care of you. Make sure he gets admitted right away.
On the bright side it'll be interesting to see what it feels like to be a patient here.
You know people die here?
You're a good friend.
Eh, I do what I can. Can I have your stuff?
So did you talk to any girls last night?
Baby, I'm an attractive man we both know this. It's just a burden you'll have to live with.
One of many.
J.D. talked some girl up
Really are you gonna call her?
Eh! Eck!
Not right away.
Alright, showtime. Clear out so I can check em out.
Whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah, whoah. You're examining me? I don't want you to see my unmentionables.
I've seen underwear before.
Actually I use the word unmentionables for my genitals as well.
Sixty-eight year old male with respiratory distress and tightness in-
Save your breath. Hello Dad.
Never thought you'd call me that again after I left.
Dr. Cox!
Relax Carla the man I'm smothering isn't really my father. Dr Benson used to be the chief of medicine here.
Oh hi how are ya?
Still have that great rapport with the nurses huh?
Actually Carla totally gets me. That's why I've been systematically trying to driver her away.
You ever see that therapist I recommended?
Not yet, no.
Shortness of breath, dizziness, problems urinating?
No, no, is it a problem if it whistles?
Oh, you're making this so much easier! Are you sexually active?
Oh it's active.
I'll write, rare dry spell in the margin. Okay time for the physical
Cold hands.
Suck it up!
Elliot's exam was frighteningly reminiscent of when my older brother used to beat the crap out of me.
Ow!
See that wasn't so bad. All done.
I'm still puking every hour and my fever's pretty high but you're sure it's okay for me to be out of bed right?
I don't know Dr. Benson was kind of my mentor, so don't do that annoying thing.
What annoying thing?
You know when you talk.
Come on that's a little-
See there it is. How does that not drive you crazy?
I know you're all excited because got the gown on but under no circumstance are you to curtsy.
He can say what he wants. The bottom line is he's showing me off.
Watching Dr. Cox I realized we never really stop craving the attention of people we look up to.
Any questions? Great.
He seemed nice.
Careful newbie.
You know I'm hearing it now it is kind of annoying when I talk.
I guess in a lot of relationships you regress to the person you were when you first met.
So Elliot's uh exam was that bad ay?
Dude she violated me.
In a good way?!
What's the deal?
Ah! I think I broke my ass!
I heard you're telling everyone I violated you.
Not everyone, just the people that work here. Oh and my parents.
Was there something wrong with my exam?
So there it is a classic trap. Two choices, either wuss out or tell the truth.
Well, you're kinda rough, yeah you're rough. And you're a little business like. Oh and you're cold.
Mm hm you mean my hands?
Yeah, those too. I just think you know you could be more comforting.
I could tell she appreciated how hard it was for me to say that.
Do you know how annoying you are when you talk?
Maybe not.
Hey I was watching that!
It's broken.
Dr. Cox, did you get my memo reminding all senior staff that lab coats must be worn at all times?

You know I did get it there Bob, and at first I just threw it away. But then I decided that wasn't a grand enough gesture. So I made a replica of you out of straw and then I put my lab coat on it with your memo in the pocket and then I invited all the kids in the neighborhood to come over and light it on fire and whack it with sticks.
Uh huh, so I've been looking at Dr. Benson's chart. His chest X Ray was normal, his vitals are stable. So let's discharge him.
Well now hold the phone there Skipper. Now, Dr. Benson should be able to stay here until he feels he's ready to go. I mean give me a break he was only the chief of medicine for ten years!
Well, I haven't had my coffee yet so I'm finding it hard coming up with a more colorful way to say who gives a crap? Actually that wasn't half bad.
Our next patient is a twenty-six year old male who has presented vomiting, abdominal cramps, and fever.
I guess I never realized how hard rounds are on the patient. It feels like you're on display.
Still Rodin's masterpiece makes us wonder, why didn't he spend a little less time thinking and a little more time at the gym?
I do cardio.
Which most likely indicates what Dr. Reid?
I'd say he has a simple case of appendicitis.
And how would you proceed Dr. Dorian?
Well, for starters I would've given me that news in private no matter how angry I was at me.
Sounds like there's some fascinating back story here, turf him to surgery. Moving on.
You better watch it Bambi you don't want a hundred pound white girl mad at you. You'll flinch every time you hear a range rover.
